results.webTitle: Felix and the Hidden Treasure ‚Äì family animation flounders as satire

fields.headline: Felix and the Hidden Treasure ‚Äì family animation flounders as satire
fields.standfirst: A boy searches for his father in a decent-looking adventure that ditches that narrative for a kid-unfriendly one about a cult
fields.trailText: A boy searches for his father in a decent-looking adventure that ditches that narrative for a kid-unfriendly one about a cult
fields.body:
This is a semi-entertaining, reasonably decent family animation that begins promisingly with a swell of adventure as a young boy sets sail in a boat in search of his missing dad. But after a couple of hastily resolved peril-at-sea moments (‚ÄúWe‚Äôre done for! We‚Äôre saved!‚Äù) the script lurches into a bizarrely un-childfriendly storyline about a secretive cult.

The boy is 12-year-old Felix (nicely voiced by Daniel Brochu), who lives in Quebec‚Äôs Magdalen Islands with his mum and little sister. Two years earlier, his fisherman dad was lost at sea. Any hope that he might be alive is long gone, but Felix is determined to search the island where he was last spotted. He ropes in grumpy lighthouse-keeper Tom to help ‚Äì a real old Captain Birdseye with a bushy beard and eyebrows like furry white caterpillars.

There are some gracefully animated scenes as the pair sail off, all glowing sunsets and churning waves. But when they get shipwrecked, it all goes headspinningly wrong. They discover that an evil cult has built an underground city on the island where Felix‚Äôs dad went missing. The group‚Äôs leader Morg√§a (Karine Vanasse), a woman with flicky, over-the-top Real Housewives hair and bling sunglasses, rejects the label ‚Äúcult‚Äù. ‚ÄúThe residents come here entirely of their own accord,‚Äù she trills. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôve adopted a peaceful, sincere lifestyle based on principles of harmony.‚Äù This satire of lifestyle gurus here is pretty low on gags, and it‚Äôs hard to see how it will connect with younger viewers.

The rest of the movie plays out in standard kids‚Äô entertainment frantic mode, the group‚Äôs security beefcakes chasing Felix and Tom around, everyone bopping each other on the head. Spoiler alert: Morg√§a‚Äôs power is linked to immortality; adults get turned into babies, kids are threatened with premature ageing. It‚Äôs a neat idea, but the script doesn‚Äôt take it anywhere interesting.

‚Ä¢ Felix and the Hidden Treasure is released on 4 June in cinemas.

fields.headline: ‚ÄòMy hairline threatened my identity so much the ground felt shaky‚Äô: why hair transplants are booming
fields.standfirst: Celebrity endorsements, new techniques and lockdown have led to rising demand for follicular transplants. But with patchy regulation, are men being exploited when they are vulnerable?
fields.trailText: Celebrity endorsements, new techniques and lockdown have led to rising demand for follicular transplants. But with patchy regulation, are men being exploited when they are vulnerable?
fields.body:
Hamish says he‚Äôs not at all vain. He wouldn‚Äôt consider getting his teeth whitened. He has an average life, with a happy marriage and two children. But when he caught sight of the top of his head in a family photo about eight years ago, something consumed him.

‚ÄúI just saw this massive receding hairline and it triggered intense emotions,‚Äù he says from his home in Edinburgh, where he works in marketing. ‚ÄúI can feel my heart rate has increased just talking about it. It somehow threatens my identity so much that the ground feels shaky.‚Äù

For years Hamish, who is in his mid 40s and prefers not to share his real name, did little about his loss. He was busy, and paralysing shame mingled with dread. But the pandemic changed that. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve had too much time to think, too much time to look in the mirror,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúAnd throw into that the whole Zoom malarkey, where I was constantly faced with the last thing I wanted to see ‚Ä¶ It took over my life and I thought: ‚ÄòLook, I‚Äôm going to get this fixed.‚Äô‚Äù

Lockdowns have presented a challenge and opportunity to men who are worried about hair loss. Many looked down from unforgiving mirrors and webcams to healthy bank balances. With offices closed, and nights out and holidays on hold, social confinement has also provided the perfect cover for recovery, out of sight. The result is that the procedure is now in unprecedented demand.

The British Association of Hair Restoration Surgery (Bahrs) estimates that the country has about 100 doctors doing hair transplant surgery via more than 200 clinics ‚Äì 10 times the number there was a decade ago. Transplant tourism has also exploded, particularly in Turkey, where clinics offer package deals including hotels for as little as ¬£1,000 ‚Äì half the rate at even the cheapest UK clinics. But pandemic travel restrictions have concentrated demand at clinics in this country. Dr Richard Rogers, a veteran surgeon at the Westminster Clinic in London, has a packed diary, and reports a 50% pandemic bounce in inquiries.

Related: 'It can leave your self-image fractured': how hair loss hits men ‚Äì and what they can do about it

Many surgeons do impeccable work. But an increasing number of clinics operate in a follicular wild west, where competition is fierce and regulation is patchy. They tend to prioritise tough sales tactics and search engine optimisation over training and well-equipped treatment rooms. And now they are exploiting the pandemic and the male insecurity it has fuelled.

‚ÄúRelationships have broken down, jobs have been lost and people want to better themselves,‚Äù says Spencer Stevenson, a mentor for balding men, who is known online as Spex. He says inquiries to his own site have quadrupled in the past year ‚Äì up to 50 messages a day. He says a culture of peer permission is taking root, challenging the stigma associated with balding cures; everyone seems to have a mate of a mate who has had a transplant. ‚ÄúBut I feel really sorry for new patients,‚Äù he adds. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got vulnerable, naive men walking into this brutal place.‚Äù

Stevenson, 45, was that man when he got his first transplant 20 years ago in the US. It was the era when hair plugs were sparse and unnaturally spaced, like a doll‚Äôs hair. Stevenson has since had 12 corrective and further transplants, spending more than ¬£30,000. He now has an enviable mop, and says if he were starting the same journey, transplant technology is such that one or two good operations would do the same job.

After administering local anaesthetic, surgeons today use a needle-like tool to punch out units of up to four healthy hairs, including their root-like follicles. Thousands of these follicular units can be smuggled out of thicker areas of hair, usually at the back of the head. Doctors then insert these units, or grafts, into balding areas via tiny cuts to the scalp. Some clinics use robots to make the incisions. Patients emerge with thousands of sting-like scars, which heal quickly. The implanted hairs typically drop out in shock but regrow over the coming weeks, like green shoots after a forest fire. It can take a year to see the full results. Done well, a transplant should look totally natural.

Follicular unit extraction (FUE), as this method is known, is in the highest demand, including at less reputable clinics. An alternative, known as follicular unit transplantation (FUT), involves the slicing out of a strip of scalp. This string-like length of hairy flesh is then sliced into units for implantation. FUT can yield more grafts for extensive transplants, but also leaves a bigger, permanent scar.

When the Guardian asked men to share their experiences of hair transplant surgery, more than 100 responded. Most were happy. ‚ÄúIt was fantastic,‚Äù says Matt, 40, a postman from Devon, who went to Istanbul for his transplant last October, when travel restrictions were relaxed. He paid ¬£1,450, including three nights in a hotel. ‚ÄúIt didn‚Äôt really hurt and I‚Äôm very happy with the results so far.‚Äù

James Collins, 26, is from Newcastle and travelled to Birmingham in January for his ¬£5,000 transplant. He had always avoided being photographed because his receding hairline got him down. He says that while he wasn‚Äôt hiding his transplant, lockdown let him recover without facing questions from friends. ‚ÄúIt has made a world of difference to my confidence,‚Äù he says.

While none of the respondents had suffered serious adverse effects, some patients said they had regrets. They sought a comforting bedside manner and value for money, and were shocked to discover a world of upselling, poor communication, unqualified technicians, and treatment rooms that, in the words of one dismayed patient, felt more like a ‚Äústore cupboard‚Äù.

Tom is in his late 30s, and also prefers not to use his real name. He has watched his hair retreat for eight years. ‚ÄúMy other half loves it ‚Äì Jason Statham is his ideal man ‚Äì but it just didn‚Äôt make me feel confident,‚Äù he says. At first Tom‚Äôs partner talked him out of surgery. But the comedian Jimmy Carr changed his mind. Celebrity recipients have helped drive the boom since Wayne Rooney restored his hairline in 2011. Carr revealed his pandemic transplant on TV last year. ‚ÄúWhat else are you going to do in lockdown?‚Äù he said.

Tom hit Google, which is often where the trouble starts. Searches for ‚Äúhair transplant‚Äù yield millions of results, the vast majority of which are for competing clinics. ‚ÄúClassic red flags are: ‚ÄòWe can get you in tomorrow‚Äô, ‚ÄòWe‚Äôll offer you a discount‚Äô, and ‚ÄòWe‚Äôve just had a cancellation‚Äô,‚Äù Stevenson says. ‚ÄúWhat you want is a clinic who can‚Äôt get you in for six months; where the price is the price. But when you‚Äôre vulnerable, you hear what you want to hear and a lot of clinics know what buttons to press.‚Äù Other warning signs, he says, include claims of ‚Äúguaranteed results‚Äù, ‚Äúunlimited grafts‚Äù and ‚Äúscarless surgery‚Äù.

Related: I thought about a wig and tried a comb-over. But now I‚Äôm bald and proud

Reports of botched transplants are common and Rogers, at the Westminster Clinic, says he is frequently called to repair them. Greg Williams, a former NHS burns surgeon, switched to hair transplants in 2012. He is now president of Bahrs and lobbies for better regulation. There is no register for cosmetic surgery because it‚Äôs not a recognised medical specialism. ‚ÄúBut I would suggest hair transplant surgery isn‚Äôt cosmetic ‚Äì it‚Äôs a treatment for a medical condition,‚Äù he says. Recognition would increase regulation. In the meantime, it is left largely to clinics to set their own standards.
